title: Prefixes — un- and re-
description: Students learn how the prefixes un- (not/opposite) and re- (again) change word meanings. They build new words using prefix cards and a base word list, then use them in sentences.
instructions:
1. Introduce the concept of a prefix: a group of letters added to the beginning of a word that changes its meaning.
2. Present the prefix un-: means 'not' or 'opposite of.' Examples: unhappy, unkind, unlock, unfair.
3. Present the prefix re-: means 'again.' Examples: redo, rewrite, rebuild, replay.
4. The child combines prefix cards with base word cards to build new words.
5. Write 5 sentences using words with un- and 5 with re-.
6. Start a vocabulary journal page for prefixes.

slides.heading: Prefixes
slides.subheading: un- and re- — Word Building Power
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure! It tells us we're going to learn about special word parts called "prefixes," and we'll focus on two exciting ones: "un-" and "re-." Think of them as secret codes that give words new powers!

items: Prefix cards: un- and re- (multiple copies)
Base word cards: happy, kind, fair, lock, do, tie, wrap, safe, lucky, real, write, build, play, read, tell, fill, view, paint, start, use
slides.setup_instructions: Write prefix cards on one color of card stock and base word cards on another. Spread base words on the table. Have the vocabulary journal open to a fresh page titled 'Prefixes.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our tools ready for some word building! We have special cards with "un-" and "re-" on them, and other cards with words like "happy" and "write." We'll also need our vocabulary journal and some pencils to write down all the amazing new words we create. You'll need a grown-up to help you gather these!

slides.text: A prefix is like a key that unlocks a new meaning. When we add letters to the BEGINNING of a word, we create a new word. Today we will learn two powerful prefixes.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about understanding what a prefix is. Imagine a prefix is like a little superhero at the start of a word that changes its whole superpower, or meaning! We're going to learn how adding these letters to the *beginning* of a word makes a brand new word.

slides.text: The prefix un- means 'not' or 'the opposite of.' Place the un- card in front of 'happy.' Now you have 'unhappy' — the opposite of happy! Try un- with 'kind,' 'fair,' 'lock,' and 'tie.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to play with the prefix "un-." This prefix is like saying "not" or "the opposite of." So, if you put "un-" in front of "happy," you get "unhappy," which means *not* happy! Try putting "un-" in front of "kind" and "fair" and see what new words you can make.

slides.text: The prefix re- means 'again.' Place the re- card in front of 'write.' Now you have 'rewrite' — to write again! Try re- with 'build,' 'play,' 'read,' and 'paint.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we meet the prefix "re-." This prefix means "again." So, if you have the word "write," and you add "re-" to the beginning, you get "rewrite," which means to write it *again*! Let's try putting "re-" in front of words like "build" and "play."

slides.prompt: Build as many real words as you can with un- and re-. Write each word and its meaning in your vocabulary journal. Then write 5 sentences: use a word with un- in each of the first 3, and a word with re- in the last 2.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to build some awesome words! You'll take the "un-" and "re-" cards and put them in front of the base word cards to make new words. Write down each new word and what it means in your journal, then write some sentences using your cool new words. You've got this!

slides.text: You have unlocked word-building power! When you see un- or re- at the beginning of a word, you can figure out the meaning. Look for these prefixes in your reading this week!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly build at least 8 words with un- and re-, and explain how the prefix changes the meaning?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You've become a word-building superhero by learning how "un-" and "re-" can change words. You can now look at words like "unlucky" or "replay" and know exactly what they mean without even trying! Keep an eye out for these prefixes when you're reading.

parent_notes: Prefix study is one of the most efficient ways to build vocabulary. A child who knows 10 prefixes can decode hundreds of unfamiliar words. Not every base word works with every prefix — 'un-play' is not a real word, but 'replay' is. Let the child discover which combinations work and which do not. This trial-and-error builds word awareness.

title: Adding Like Fractions — Fraction Insets
description: Students learn to add fractions with the same denominator using the Montessori fraction insets. They physically combine fraction pieces and record the addition equations.
instructions:
1. Review fraction vocabulary: numerator, denominator.
2. Demonstrate: 1/4 + 2/4. Place 1 fourth-piece and then 2 more fourth-pieces in the circle. Count: 3 fourths = 3/4.
3. Explain: When denominators are the same, we add the numerators and keep the denominator.
4. Practice with halves, thirds, and fourths.
5. Introduce sums that equal a whole: 1/3 + 2/3 = 3/3 = 1 whole.
6. Record all equations in the math journal.

slides.heading: Adding Fractions
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide tells us what we're going to learn about today: adding fractions that have the same bottom number. It's like putting together puzzle pieces that are all the same shape!

items: Montessori fraction insets (halves, thirds, fourths, fifths, sixths)
slides.setup_instructions: Set out fraction insets with the whole circle frame. Have the math journal open. Prepare 8-10 addition problems with like denominators.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our tools ready for this fraction adventure! We'll need those colorful fraction insets – the ones that make up a whole circle. We also need our math journal and a pencil to write down our discoveries, and colored pencils to draw our fraction answers.

slides.text: Review: hold up 1/4. 'The bottom number (4) tells us the whole is divided into 4 parts. The top number (1) tells us we have 1 of those parts.' Now let us add fractions!
slides.mascot_explanation: This first step is like learning the secret code of fractions. Remember, the bottom number, called the denominator, tells us how many equal pieces make up the whole thing, like how many slices are in a whole pizza. The top number, the numerator, tells us how many of those pieces we actually have, like how many slices you get to eat!

slides.text: Place 1 fourth-piece in the frame. Now add 2 more fourth-pieces. Count: 'One-fourth plus two-fourths equals... three-fourths!' Write: 1/4 + 2/4 = 3/4. The denominator stays the same because the pieces are the same size.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the fun part – adding! We're going to take one of the fourth-sized pieces and put it in our circle. Then, we'll add two more of those fourth-sized pieces right next to it. See how they fit together perfectly? When we count them up, we have three fourth-sized pieces, which we write as 1/4 + 2/4 = 3/4. The bottom number stays a 4 because all our pieces are the same size – fourths!

slides.text: Try 1/3 + 2/3. Place pieces in the frame. Count them. 'Three-thirds fills the whole circle! Three-thirds equals one whole.' Write: 1/3 + 2/3 = 3/3 = 1.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's try another one! This time, we're adding thirds. Put one third-piece in the circle, and then add two more third-pieces. Wow, look at that – the three pieces fill the whole circle up perfectly! That means three-thirds is the same as one whole thing, so we write 1/3 + 2/3 = 3/3 = 1. Isn't it neat how fractions can make a whole?

slides.prompt: Solve these with the fraction insets and record in your journal: 1/2 + 1/2, 1/4 + 1/4, 2/5 + 1/5, 1/6 + 3/6, 2/4 + 2/4, 1/3 + 1/3, 3/6 + 2/6, 1/5 + 3/5. Draw each problem with colored fraction pieces.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the fraction explorer! Use your fraction pieces to solve each problem on the screen, and then draw what you did in your math journal. Remember to count your pieces and write down the answer, just like we practiced. You've got this!

slides.text: When fractions have the same denominator, adding is simple: just add the top numbers! The denominator stays the same because the size of the pieces does not change. You are a fraction master!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child add like fractions using the insets and explain why the denominator stays the same?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You've become a fraction master today by adding fractions with the same bottom number. It's super simple, right? You just add the top numbers together, and the bottom number stays the same because the size of the pieces never changes. That's the coolest part!

parent_notes: The key concept is that when denominators match, the pieces are the same size, so we simply count how many pieces we have. The fraction insets make this concrete. Let the child physically combine pieces before writing equations. If they struggle, go back to naming fractions before adding them. This foundation is critical for unlike fractions later.

title: Ancient Egypt — Pharaohs and Pyramids
description: Students are introduced to Ancient Egypt through the story of the Nile River and its annual flood cycle. They learn why Egypt was called 'the gift of the Nile' and how the river made civilization possible.
instructions:
1. Show a map of Egypt highlighting the Nile River.
2. Tell the story: Every year the Nile flooded, depositing rich black soil on the banks. This made farming possible in the desert.
3. Compare to Mesopotamia: both river civilizations, but different rivers and different challenges.
4. Discuss: Upper Egypt (south) and Lower Egypt (north) — why the names seem backwards.
5. The child draws a map of Egypt showing the Nile, delta, and desert.
6. Timeline work: place Egypt on the timeline (3100 BCE - 30 BCE).

slides.heading: Ancient Egypt
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our adventure book about Ancient Egypt! It tells us the name of the place we're going to learn about and a super important clue: "The Gift of the Nile." This means the Nile River was really, really special to the people who lived there.

items: Map of Ancient Egypt (printed or in atlas)
slides.setup_instructions: Display the Egypt map prominently. Have the timeline accessible for adding Egypt. Prepare drawing paper and blue drawing tools.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, let's get our explorer tools ready! We'll need that map of Egypt so we can see where we're going, a timeline to help us know *when* this happened way back in history, some paper and colored pencils for drawing, and a blue crayon or marker for the river. You might also need that book about Egypt if we want to look up cool pictures.

slides.text: Look at the map. Egypt is in northeastern Africa, mostly desert. But running through it is the longest river in the world — the Nile! Every year, the Nile flooded, leaving rich black mud on its banks. This mud was perfect for growing crops.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is showing us a map of Egypt. See how it's mostly yellow and brown? That's desert! But look, there's a big blue line going right through it – that's the Nile River, the longest river in the whole world! Every year, this river would flood, like a super big bathtub overflow, and leave behind special mud that was perfect for growing yummy food.

slides.text: The Greek historian Herodotus called Egypt 'the gift of the Nile.' Without the river, Egypt would be nothing but desert. The Egyptians depended on the flood. They built their entire civilization along the river's banks.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a really cool idea called "the gift of the Nile." It means that Egypt was like a present from the river! Without the Nile's floods leaving that rich mud, the desert would just be sand, and people couldn't grow enough food to live there. So, they built their whole lives right along the river because it gave them everything they needed.

slides.text: Compare Egypt to Mesopotamia: both grew along rivers, both invented writing, both built great monuments. But Egypt had one long river while Mesopotamia had two. Egypt was protected by desert on both sides, making it harder to invade.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here we're comparing Egypt to another ancient place called Mesopotamia. Both places were amazing because they grew up next to rivers, which helped them farm and build big things. But Egypt had just one long river, the Nile, and it was surrounded by deserts, which kept enemies away, making it a bit safer than Mesopotamia.

slides.prompt: Draw a map of Ancient Egypt. Include: the Nile River (in blue), the Mediterranean Sea (north), the Red Sea (east), the desert (yellow) on both sides, the Nile Delta where the river meets the sea, and mark Upper Egypt (south) and Lower Egypt (north). Add the timeline entry for Egypt.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to be artists and mapmakers! You get to draw your very own map of Ancient Egypt. First, draw that big blue Nile River, then add the seas around it, and color the sandy deserts on each side. Don't forget the part where the river spreads out like a fan at the end, called the delta, and remember to label the north and south parts of Egypt. You'll also add Egypt to our timeline!

slides.text: Egypt lasted over 3,000 years — longer than almost any civilization in history! The Nile made it all possible. This week we will explore the pharaohs, pyramids, and mummies of this incredible civilization.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain why Egypt was called 'the gift of the Nile' and identify the Nile, delta, and desert on a map?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You made a map of Ancient Egypt and learned why the Nile River was so important. Think about that – a whole amazing civilization grew because of a river's yearly flood! We're going to keep learning about the super cool pharaohs and mysterious mummies next time.

parent_notes: This lesson establishes the geographic foundation for the entire Egypt unit. The key understanding is that geography shapes civilization — the Nile made Egypt possible just as the Tigris and Euphrates made Mesopotamia possible. The 'Upper/Lower' Egypt naming confuses many children (and adults!) — explain that the Nile flows north, so Upper Egypt is upstream (south) and Lower Egypt is downstream (north).

title: Egypt — Physical and Political Geography
description: Students study Egypt's physical geography (Nile River, Sahara Desert, Sinai Peninsula, Red Sea) and modern political geography (borders, capital Cairo, major cities).
instructions:
1. Examine a physical map of Egypt: identify deserts, Nile valley, delta, Sinai.
2. Examine a political map: borders with Libya, Sudan, Israel; capital Cairo.
3. Discuss how ancient and modern Egypt overlap geographically.
4. The child creates a two-panel map: physical features on one side, political on the other.
5. Label key features on both maps.
6. Compare Egypt's size to the child's home state/country.

slides.heading: Egypt
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our book about Egypt! It tells us we're going to learn about its geography, which is all about the land, water, and where things are located. We'll be looking at both how the land looks naturally and how people have drawn lines on maps to make countries and cities.

items: Political map of Egypt (showing borders, cities)
Large drawing paper folded in half
slides.setup_instructions: Display both maps. Fold drawing paper in half — one side for physical, one for political. Have colored pencils sorted: blue for water, yellow for desert, green for fertile land.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool stuff we need to make our own maps of Egypt! We've got a physical map that shows mountains and rivers, and a political map that shows borders and cities. Then we have big paper that's already folded in half, just waiting for us to draw on. And of course, we need our colorful pencils and markers to make our maps look awesome!

slides.text: Physical geography: Egypt is 95% desert! The Sahara Desert covers the west, the Eastern Desert lies between the Nile and the Red Sea. The Sinai Peninsula connects Egypt to Asia. And the Nile cuts through it all, creating a thin green ribbon of fertile land.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to look at the *physical* map of Egypt, which means how the land itself looks. Imagine a giant sandbox – that's most of Egypt, called the Sahara Desert! But look, there's a big blue line, the Nile River, and it makes the land around it super green and good for growing things. We also see the Sinai Peninsula sticking out, which is like a land bridge to another continent!

slides.text: Political geography: Egypt borders Libya to the west, Sudan to the south, and Israel to the northeast. The capital is Cairo — one of the largest cities in Africa! Alexandria is on the Mediterranean coast.
slides.mascot_explanation: This next slide is all about the *political* map, which is how people have divided up the land. We can see the borders of Egypt and the countries next door, like Libya and Sudan. And right in the middle, there's Cairo, the super-duper big capital city where lots of people live!

slides.text: On the left panel, draw Egypt's physical features: the Nile, Sahara, Eastern Desert, Red Sea, Mediterranean Sea, Sinai Peninsula, Nile Delta. On the right panel, draw the political map with borders, neighboring countries, and major cities.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to get creative and make our own maps! On one side of your paper, you're going to draw the natural things we just learned about, like the big yellow desert and the blue Nile River. On the other side, you'll draw the political map with all the country lines and important cities like Cairo.

slides.prompt: Complete both map panels. Physical side: color the desert yellow, the Nile blue, fertile land green, and label all major features. Political side: draw borders, label neighboring countries, mark Cairo, Alexandria, and Luxor. Add a compass rose to each.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be a map-making superstar! You'll color in all the parts of Egypt on both sides of your paper – yellow for the deserts, blue for the water, and green for the green land. Make sure to write the names of everything you draw, like the Nile River and Cairo, and don't forget to add a compass rose so you know which way is north!

slides.text: Egypt is where Africa meets Asia, where desert meets river, where ancient meets modern. The same Nile that fed the pharaohs still flows through Cairo today. Over 100 million people live in Egypt!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child label the Nile, Sahara, Red Sea, and Sinai on a physical map and identify Egypt's capital and at least 2 neighboring countries?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at what you've done! You've created a fantastic map showing both the natural wonders and the human-made borders of Egypt. You learned that most of Egypt is desert, but the Nile River makes it possible for people to live and grow food, and you even know where the capital city is! You're a real geography whiz!

parent_notes: This lesson connects ancient and modern Egypt through geography. Children are often surprised that Egypt is mostly desert and that nearly everyone lives along the Nile. This is a great opportunity to discuss population density. If possible, use Google Earth to zoom into the Nile valley and see the stark contrast between green farmland and desert.

title: Read Aloud — Pharaohs and Pyramids Introduction
description: Begin reading an engaging book about Ancient Egypt, introducing the pharaohs and pyramids. This sets the stage for the quarter's history studies with vivid storytelling.
instructions:
1. Introduce the book and show the cover illustrations.
2. Read Chapter 1 or the introduction aloud.
3. Pause for predictions: What will we learn about?
4. Discuss new vocabulary: pharaoh, dynasty, pyramid, sphinx.
5. The child writes new vocabulary words and definitions in their journal.
6. Preview what comes next in the book.

slides.heading: Pharaohs and Pyramids
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is the title of our new adventure! It tells us we're going to be reading all about pharaohs and pyramids in Ancient Egypt. Think of it like the cover of a really exciting storybook that's going to teach us about a super old and amazing place.

items: Ancient Egypt book (e.g., 'Pharaohs and Foot Soldiers,' 'The Story of the World Ch. 2-4,' or 'Ancient Egypt Revealed')
slides.setup_instructions: Select an age-appropriate Egypt book. Bookmark the first chapter. Have vocabulary cards and the reading journal ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our supplies ready for our Egyptian journey! You'll need the book about Ancient Egypt – it's like our map to the past. We also need your reading journal and a pencil to write down cool new words we learn. And see those blank cards? We'll use those to make our own special dictionary of Egyptian words.

slides.text: Show the book cover. 'This quarter we are reading about Ancient Egypt — one of the greatest civilizations in history. Look at the cover. What do you see? What do you think we will learn about?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's look at the cover of our book! See all those pictures? This slide wants you to look closely and think about what the book might be about. What do you see on the cover that makes you curious, and what do you think we'll discover in our reading today?

slides.text: Read the first chapter aloud. Use an engaging, dramatic voice. Pause at new vocabulary: 'A pharaoh was the king of Egypt. Dynasty means a family that rules for many generations. Let us add these to our vocabulary cards.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to hear an amazing story! We're going to read the first part of our book together, and I'll use my best storytelling voice. When we hear words like "pharaoh" (that's like a king!) or "dynasty" (that's a whole family of rulers!), we'll stop and make sure we understand them.

slides.text: After reading, discuss: 'What surprised you? What do you want to know more about? How is Egypt similar to or different from Mesopotamia?'
slides.mascot_explanation: After we finish reading, we get to talk about everything we learned! Think about what was the most surprising thing you heard, or what you're super excited to learn more about. We'll also chat about how Ancient Egypt might be different from places we know, like maybe where we live.

slides.prompt: Create vocabulary cards for 5 new Egypt words: pharaoh, dynasty, pyramid, sphinx, and one more from the reading. Write the word on the front and the definition plus a small drawing on the back. Then write 3 predictions about what we will learn next.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be the expert! We're going to make special flashcards for important Egyptian words like pharaoh, pyramid, and sphinx. You'll write the word on one side and what it means and a little drawing on the other. Then, you'll write down three guesses about what cool things we'll learn in our next reading session.

slides.text: Egypt is full of mysteries and wonders! We will read more each week. Keep your vocabulary cards handy — you will become an Egypt expert!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child define pharaoh and pyramid, and make at least one prediction about the upcoming reading?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we learned so much about Egypt today! We're going to keep reading more exciting stories about pharaohs and pyramids each week, so get ready to become a total Ancient Egypt whiz. Keep those vocabulary cards safe, because they'll help you remember all the amazing things we discover!

parent_notes: Good read-aloud options for this age: 'The Story of the World Vol. 1' by Susan Wise Bauer (chapters on Egypt), 'National Geographic Ancient Egypt' by Jill Rubalcaba, 'Ancient Egypt' DK Eyewitness, or 'Pharaohs and Foot Soldiers' by Kristin Butcher. Read-alouds should be slightly above independent reading level to stretch vocabulary and comprehension.

title: Prefixes — pre- and dis-
description: Students learn the prefixes pre- (before) and dis- (not/opposite/apart). They build words, discover meaning changes, and add to their vocabulary journals.
instructions:
1. Review un- and re- from yesterday.
2. Introduce pre-: means 'before.' Examples: preview, preheat, prehistoric, preschool.
3. Introduce dis-: means 'not,' 'opposite,' or 'apart.' Examples: disagree, disappear, disconnect, discover.
4. The child builds words with prefix cards and base words.
5. Play a prefix matching game: match the prefix to the correct base word.
6. Write sentences using all four prefixes learned so far.

slides.heading: More Prefixes
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure today! It's telling us we're going to learn about two more special word parts called prefixes, "pre-" and "dis-". We already know "un-" and "re-", so these are like adding more superpowers to our word-building toolbelt!

items: Prefix cards: pre-, dis-, un-, re-
Base word cards: view, heat, historic, school, pay, test, agree, appear, connect, cover, obey, like, order, approve, own, honor
slides.setup_instructions: Add the new prefix cards to the existing set. Prepare new base word cards. Open the vocabulary journal to the prefix page started yesterday.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, look at all these cards! We have some special cards with our prefixes – "pre-", "dis-", "un-", and "re-" – and then lots of other cards with the main parts of words, called base words. We'll use these cards to build new words! You'll also need your vocabulary journal and a pencil to write down all the cool new words we discover. Make sure you have all these ready to go!

slides.text: Quick review: What does un- mean? (not/opposite) What does re- mean? (again) Great! Today we learn two more prefix superpowers.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is a quick check-in, like a warm-up before the big game. It's asking us to remember what "un-" means – remember, it means "not" or "the opposite" – and what "re-" means, which is "again." Think about words like "unhappy" or "redo" to help you remember!

slides.text: The prefix pre- means 'before.' Preview means to view before. Preheat means to heat before. Prehistoric means before history was written! Place pre- in front of base words and discover new meanings.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to meet "pre-"! This prefix is like a time machine because "pre-" means "before." So, if you "preview" something, you see it *before* it happens, and if you "preheat" the oven, you warm it up *before* you bake. We're going to put "pre-" in front of some words and see what new meanings pop up!

slides.text: The prefix dis- means 'not' or 'the opposite of' or 'apart.' Disagree means to not agree. Disappear means to not appear anymore. Disconnect means to separate apart. Try dis- with these words: like, obey, order, approve.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now let's explore "dis-," which is another super useful prefix! "Dis-" can mean "not," like in "disagree" (when you don't agree), or it can mean "apart," like when you "disconnect" something. It can also mean "the opposite of." We'll try putting "dis-" in front of words like "like" and "obey" to see how the meaning changes!

slides.prompt: In your vocabulary journal, add pre- and dis- with 5 example words each. Then write a short story (5-8 sentences) that uses at least one word with each of the four prefixes: un-, re-, pre-, dis-. Underline the prefix words.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be the word builder and storyteller! First, you'll add "pre-" and "dis-" to your journal, writing down five new words for each, just like we did yesterday. Then, the really fun part: you'll write a short story using words with "un-," "re-," "pre-," and "dis-." Make sure you underline those special prefix words when you're done!

slides.text: You now know four prefixes: un-, re-, pre-, dis-. These four alone help you understand hundreds of English words! When you see an unfamiliar word, check if it has a prefix you know.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child define all four prefixes and use each in a sentence with a correctly formed word?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you've done it! You now know four powerful prefixes: "un-," "re-," "pre-," and "dis-." That's a lot of word knowledge! Remember, when you see a word you don't know, look for these prefixes – they can help you figure out the whole word's meaning, just like a detective finding clues!

parent_notes: Prefix knowledge is one of the strongest predictors of reading comprehension in elementary students. When the child encounters an unknown word in reading, prompt them: 'Do you see a prefix? What does it mean? What might the whole word mean?' This strategy transfers across all subjects. The short story activity integrates creative writing with vocabulary.

title: Fractions of a Set — Concrete to Pictorial
description: Students learn to find a fraction of a set of objects (e.g., 1/3 of 12 counters). They progress from hands-on manipulation to drawing and then to numerical computation.
instructions:
1. Present 12 counters. 'Let us find 1/3 of 12.'
2. Divide the counters into 3 equal groups. Each group is 1/3. Count one group: 4.
3. So 1/3 of 12 = 4. Write the equation.
4. Practice with other sets: 1/2 of 10, 1/4 of 20, 1/5 of 15.
5. Transition to drawing: draw circles, divide into groups, shade one group.
6. Connect to division: finding 1/3 of 12 is the same as 12 ÷ 3.

slides.heading: Fractions of a Set
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the title slide for our math adventure today! We're going to learn all about "Fractions of a Set," which is like figuring out what part of a group of things we're talking about. We'll start by asking a super interesting question: "What is one-third of twelve?" Isn't it exciting to solve puzzles like this?

items: 30 counters or small objects (beans, buttons, coins)
slides.setup_instructions: Count out sets of counters: 12, 10, 20, 15, 24, 18. Have sorting cups ready for dividing into groups. Open math journal to a fresh page.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our tools ready for our fraction fun! We need counters, which are like little objects we can group up, maybe beans or buttons. We also need small cups to help us sort them, a special notebook called a math journal, and a pencil to write and draw. Make sure you have all these things handy, maybe ask a grown-up to help you gather them!

slides.text: Place 12 counters on the table. 'I want to find 1/3 of 12. The denominator 3 tells me to make 3 equal groups.' Divide 12 counters into 3 groups of 4. 'Each group is 1/3. One-third of 12 is 4!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to play with our counters! Put 12 of them on your table. We want to find 1/3 of these 12 counters. The bottom number of the fraction, the 3, tells us we need to make 3 equal groups. So, carefully divide your 12 counters into 3 piles, making sure each pile has the same number. Look, each pile has 4 counters! That means 1/3 of 12 is 4!

slides.text: Try 1/2 of 10. Make 2 equal groups. Each group has 5. So 1/2 of 10 = 5. Now try 1/4 of 20. Make 4 equal groups. Each group has 5. So 1/4 of 20 = 5.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's try some more together! First, take 10 counters and make 2 equal groups. How many are in each group? That's right, 5! So, 1/2 of 10 is 5. Now, grab 20 counters and make 4 equal groups. How many are in each group this time? Yep, still 5! So, 1/4 of 20 is 5. You're getting so good at this!

slides.text: Notice the connection: finding 1/3 of 12 is the same as dividing 12 by 3. Finding 1/4 of 20 is the same as dividing 20 by 4. Fractions and division are connected!
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's a super cool secret: finding a fraction of a number is just like dividing! See how finding 1/3 of 12 was the same as dividing 12 by 3? And finding 1/4 of 20 was the same as dividing 20 by 4? It's like they're best friends who do the same job!

slides.prompt: Find these fractions of sets using counters, then draw the solution and write the equation: 1/2 of 16, 1/3 of 15, 1/4 of 24, 1/5 of 20, 1/6 of 18, 1/2 of 14. Challenge: what is 2/3 of 12? (Hint: find 1/3 first, then count 2 groups.)
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the math explorer! Use your counters to find the fractions of the sets listed, just like we practiced. After you figure out the number, draw a picture in your journal to show your work and write down the math sentence, like "1/2 of 16 = 8." Don't forget the challenge question at the end – you can do it!

slides.text: Finding a fraction of a set is dividing into equal groups. This is useful in real life: sharing pizza equally, splitting treats with friends, or dividing supplies. Fractions are about fair sharing!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child find a unit fraction of a set using counters and explain the connection to division?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did such a fantastic job today figuring out fractions of sets! You learned that finding a fraction is really just about sharing things into equal groups, just like sharing cookies or pizza with your friends. You're a super math star for connecting fractions and division!

parent_notes: The connection between fractions and division is a crucial mathematical insight. Some children grasp it immediately; others need many hands-on examples. The challenge problem (2/3 of 12) extends thinking beyond unit fractions — find 1/3 first (4), then count 2 of those groups (8). Use real-life examples: '1/4 of our 20 crayons are blue. How many blue crayons?'

title: Mammals — Characteristics and Classification
description: Students explore the defining characteristics of mammals: warm-blooded, hair/fur, live birth (mostly), nurse young with milk. They classify mammals by habitat and compare them to other vertebrate classes.
instructions:
1. Ask: What makes a mammal a mammal? Collect the child's ideas.
2. Present the defining characteristics with examples.
3. Discuss exceptions: platypus lays eggs, whale has almost no hair.
4. Sort mammal picture cards by habitat: land, water, air.
5. Compare mammals to the other vertebrate classes from Q1.
6. Start a mammal research page in the science journal.

slides.heading: Mammals
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our super cool science book about mammals! It tells us we're going to learn all about mammals and how we are actually mammals ourselves. Get ready to discover what makes us and so many other animals special!

items: Mammal picture cards (at least 20 different mammals)
3 sorting mats labeled: Land, Water, Air
slides.setup_instructions: Shuffle mammal picture cards. Set out 3 habitat sorting mats. Display the Q1 vertebrate comparison chart for reference.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this part, we need a few things to get our mammal adventure started! See these picture cards? They have all sorts of amazing mammals on them, like lions and dolphins. We also need these three mats, each one says "Land," "Water," or "Air" – these will help us sort our animal pictures. And don't forget your science journal and colored pencils to draw in later!

slides.text: We are mammals! What makes an animal a mammal? Four key traits: 1) Warm-blooded (body stays the same temperature), 2) Has hair or fur, 3) Females nurse babies with milk, 4) Most give live birth (not eggs).
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like a secret decoder ring for mammals! It tells us the four super important things that make an animal a mammal. Mammals are warm-blooded, meaning their body temperature stays the same no matter what, they have hair or fur (even if it's tiny!), mama mammals feed their babies milk, and most of them are born live instead of from eggs.

slides.text: Mammals live everywhere: on land (dogs, elephants, mice), in water (whales, dolphins, seals), and even in the air (bats are the only flying mammals!). Sort these picture cards by habitat.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for a fun sorting game! This slide reminds us that mammals live all over the place – on land like elephants, in the water like whales, and even bats fly through the air! Your job is to take those mammal picture cards and put each one on the correct mat: land, water, or air. It's like being a detective for animal homes!

slides.text: Every rule has exceptions! The platypus is a mammal that lays eggs. Whales are mammals with almost no hair. Naked mole rats have very little fur. But they all nurse their babies with milk.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like a little "gotcha!" for mammals. It tells us that even though most mammals are born live, there are a few tricky ones, like the platypus that lays eggs! And some mammals, like whales, don't have much hair at all. But remember, they *all* still feed their babies milk, which is a super big clue they are mammals.

slides.prompt: Sort all mammal cards by habitat. In your science journal, create a 'Mammals' page: list the 4 key characteristics, draw 3 mammals from different habitats, and write 2 sentences about each. Add mammals to your vertebrate comparison chart.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to become mammal experts! First, take all your mammal picture cards and sort them onto the "Land," "Water," and "Air" mats. Then, open your science journal to a new page and write down the four main mammal traits we just learned. After that, draw three different mammals from different habitats and write two sentences about each one, and finally, add mammals to the chart we used before!

slides.text: Mammals are the most diverse vertebrate class — from tiny bumblebee bats to enormous blue whales! We are mammals too. What mammal characteristics do you share? This week, we will learn more about how mammals are classified.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child list the 4 defining characteristics of mammals and classify at least 10 mammals by habitat?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You sorted all those mammals and learned what makes them so special. From the tiniest bat to the biggest whale, mammals are amazing and so diverse, and guess what? We're mammals too! It's incredible how many different kinds of mammals there are on our planet.

parent_notes: Children are fascinated to realize they are mammals! Connect the characteristics personally: 'You were warm-blooded as a baby, you have hair, you drank milk.' The exceptions (platypus, whale) show that classification is not always simple — this is real science. If possible, watch a short video of a whale nursing underwater or a bat catching insects in flight.

title: Egyptian Art — Profile Drawing and Hieroglyphic Style
description: Students study the distinctive style of Ancient Egyptian art: figures shown in profile with eyes front-facing, broad shoulders, and flat perspective. They create their own Egyptian-style drawings.
instructions:
1. Show examples of Egyptian wall paintings and relief carvings.
2. Discuss the unique style: head in profile, eye from the front, shoulders broad, legs in profile.
3. Explain this was a deliberate artistic choice, not a lack of skill.
4. The child practices drawing a figure in Egyptian style.
5. Add hieroglyphic-style borders.
6. Use warm desert colors: gold, orange, brown, blue, green.
materials_needed: Examples of Egyptian art (printed or in books)

slides.heading: Egyptian Art
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like the title page for our adventure into Ancient Egyptian art! It tells us we're going to learn how to draw just like they did thousands of years ago. Isn't it neat that we can still copy styles from so long ago?

items: Printed examples of Egyptian wall paintings
Drawing paper (tan or light brown if available)
Colored pencils, markers, or paint in Egyptian colors (gold, blue, green, red, brown)
slides.setup_instructions: Display 3-4 examples of Egyptian art showing the characteristic style. Use tan paper to simulate papyrus. Lay out art supplies.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, look at all these cool supplies! We have examples of real Egyptian paintings so we can see what we're trying to do, special tan paper that looks like old papyrus, pencils for sketching, and fun colors like gold, blue, and green that they loved to use. We also have a ruler to help us make neat borders. Go grab all these things with a grown-up so we can get started!

slides.text: Look at Egyptian art closely. Notice how every person is drawn the same way: head turned to the side, but the eye shown from the front. Shoulders face us, but the legs walk sideways. This was not a mistake — it was their artistic rule!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's look really closely at these Egyptian pictures. See how the heads are turned to the side, but the eyes are looking straight at us? And the shoulders are wide like they're facing us, but the legs are pointing sideways. That's their special way of drawing people, and it wasn't a mistake, it was their rule!

slides.text: The Egyptians wanted to show the most recognizable view of each body part. The profile of the face, the front of the eye, the width of the shoulders, the side view of the legs. This way, you could always identify the person.
slides.mascot_explanation: The ancient Egyptian artists had a clever reason for drawing like this. They wanted to show you the most important part of each body part all at once. So, you see the side of the face, the full eye, the wide shoulders, and the side view of the legs, all in one picture! It helped everyone know exactly who they were looking at.

slides.text: Let us practice! Draw a figure in Egyptian style: head in profile, eye from the front (almond-shaped), broad shoulders facing forward, arms and legs from the side. Add details: a headdress, jewelry, and traditional clothing.
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to try it ourselves! Get your pencil and paper ready. We're going to draw a person using those Egyptian rules: side-view head, front-facing eye, wide shoulders, and side-view legs. Don't forget to add cool Egyptian clothes, maybe some shiny jewelry, or even a fancy headdress! You can do it!

slides.prompt: Create an Egyptian-style drawing: draw yourself or a pharaoh in the Egyptian profile style. Add a hieroglyphic-style border around the edges using simple symbols. Color with Egyptian palette: gold, blue, green, red, white, and brown.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be the artist! Draw yourself or maybe a powerful pharaoh using the Egyptian style we just learned. Then, use your ruler and pencil to make a border with some simple Egyptian symbols, like little birds or wavy lines. Finally, use those amazing Egyptian colors – gold, blue, green, red, and brown – to make your drawing super bright and beautiful!

slides.text: Egyptian art lasted for over 3,000 years with very little change — artists followed strict rules passed down through generations. Your drawing follows those same ancient rules! Display it near your Egypt study area.
slides.mastery_check: Does the child's drawing show the characteristic Egyptian profile style with the head in profile and eye from the front?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at your amazing drawing! You followed the same special rules that Egyptian artists used for thousands of years. That's incredible! Your picture really looks like it could be from an ancient tomb, and it shows you understand the Egyptian style perfectly. Let's find a special spot to show it off!

parent_notes: Egyptian art is highly stylized and rule-based, which actually makes it accessible for children to replicate. The 'rules' provide structure that supports success. Emphasize that this was a sophisticated artistic tradition, not primitive — Egyptian artists could draw realistically but chose this style for symbolic and religious reasons. Brown paper bags can substitute for tan paper to give a papyrus feel.

title: Planning and Organizing — Weekly Work Plan Introduction
description: Students learn to create and follow a weekly work plan, a core Montessori practice that develops executive function, time management, and independence.
instructions:
1. Explain the concept of a work plan: planning your week of learning.
2. Show a blank work plan template with subjects and days.
3. Together, fill in the week's planned activities.
4. Discuss priorities: what must be done vs. what the child chooses.
5. The child decorates and personalizes their work plan.
6. Practice checking off completed work throughout the week.

slides.heading: My Work Plan
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is called "My Work Plan," and it's like a special map for your whole week of learning! It's going to help you know exactly what exciting things you'll be doing each day to learn and grow.

items: Blank weekly work plan template (grid with days and subjects)
Stickers or stamps for tracking completion
slides.setup_instructions: Print or create a weekly work plan grid with days (Mon-Fri) across the top and subjects down the side. Leave space for the child to add details and check off completed work.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our supplies ready for making our awesome work plan! We need the blank template, which is like a calendar grid, a pencil for writing your choices, colorful pencils to make it pretty, and stickers or stamps to show when you finish something super important. Go ask a grown-up to help you find these things!

slides.text: In Montessori classrooms, children help plan their own work. A work plan shows what you will do each day. It helps you take responsibility for your learning. Let us create your first weekly work plan!
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about understanding what a work plan is! Think of it like making a list of all the fun learning things you want to do this week. Doing this helps you become a super organizer and take charge of your own learning, just like big kids do!

slides.text: Look at the template: days across the top, subjects down the side. Some activities are planned by your parent (these go in pen). Others are YOUR choice (these go in pencil — you can change them!).
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's look closely at our blank work plan. See how it has the days of the week going across the top and different subjects going down the side? Some things will be written in pen because your grown-up planned them, but the things you get to choose will be in pencil so you can even change your mind if you want!

slides.text: Fill in next week's plan together. Each day has 5 activities. When you complete an activity, you check it off or place a sticker. At the end of the week, you can see everything you accomplished!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we start filling in our super cool work plan for next week! We'll decide together what you'll do each day, and when you finish something, you can put a sticker or a checkmark on it. It will be so neat to see at the end of the week how much you did!

slides.prompt: Complete your work plan for next week. Write in all planned activities. Choose 3-5 'free choice' activities from the available materials. Decorate the edges of your work plan. Post it where you can see it every day.
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to make your work plan super special and get it ready for the week! Write down all the things we decided on, and then pick 3 to 5 fun activities you really want to do from the materials we have. After that, you can decorate the edges with your colored pencils and stickers, and then hang it up somewhere you'll see it every day.

slides.text: Your work plan is YOUR map for the week. It helps you be independent and responsible. Each day, check your plan first, then get started. You are in charge of your learning!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read and understand their work plan, and explain what they will do each day?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you made your very own work plan! This is your personal guide for the week, helping you be independent and know exactly what to do. Every day, you can look at it first to see your plan and then start your amazing learning journey!

parent_notes: The work plan is a signature Montessori practice that develops executive function — the same skills needed for homework planners, calendars, and project management in later life. Start simple: list required activities and let the child choose 1-2 extras. Over time, increase their autonomy. Do not use the work plan as a punishment tool — it should feel empowering, not controlling.

title: Vocabulary Journal — Word Collection and Context Clues
description: Students set up a vocabulary journal and learn strategies for collecting new words from reading. They practice using context clues to determine word meaning before checking a dictionary.
instructions:
1. Set up the vocabulary journal: alphabetical sections, word entry format.
2. Model the entry format: word, pronunciation, part of speech, definition, sentence, illustration.
3. Read a passage together and identify 3 unfamiliar words.
4. Practice using context clues: What clues in the sentence help us guess the meaning?
5. Check guesses against a dictionary.
6. The child makes 3 complete vocabulary entries.

slides.heading: My Vocabulary Journal
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of a special book! It's called "My Vocabulary Journal," and it's where we're going to collect all sorts of cool and powerful words we find when we're reading. Think of it like collecting treasure, but the treasure is words that make us sound super smart!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare the notebook with alphabet tabs (A-B, C-D, etc. or individual letters). Model a sample entry on the first page. Have the dictionary and a reading book ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our treasure chest ready! You'll need a blank notebook that's easy to carry around, some sticky tabs to make sections for each letter of the alphabet (like A-B, C-D, and so on), a dictionary to look up word meanings, your current reading book, and a pencil and some colored pencils for drawing. Make sure to ask a grown-up to help you get all these things together!

slides.text: Powerful readers collect words! Your vocabulary journal is where you keep the interesting, unusual, or confusing words you find in your reading. Set up your journal with alphabet sections.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about getting our journal ready for our word treasures. We need to make sections in our notebook so we can easily find where to put our words later. Imagine organizing your toys so you can always find your favorite car or doll – this is like that, but for words!

slides.text: For each word entry, include: 1) The word, 2) The sentence where you found it, 3) What you THINK it means (context clue guess), 4) The dictionary definition, 5) Your own sentence using the word, 6) A small illustration.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's talk about how to record each word treasure. For every new word, you'll write down the word itself, the sentence from the book where you found it, what you *think* it means just by reading around it, what the dictionary says it means, a new sentence you make up using the word, and a little picture to help you remember it. It’s like creating a mini-story for each word!

slides.text: Let us practice with this passage. Read it aloud. When you find a word you do not know, stop. Read the sentence around it. What clues help you guess the meaning? Now check the dictionary. Were you close?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we practice being word detectives! We'll read a short story together, and when we find a word that's a mystery, we'll look at the sentences before and after it to see if there are any clues. Those clues help us guess what the word means before we even look it up in the dictionary, just like a real detective uses clues to solve a case!

slides.prompt: Find 3 unfamiliar words in your reading book. For each one, make a complete vocabulary journal entry: the word, the sentence, your guess, the dictionary definition, your own sentence, and a small drawing. Use your best handwriting.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, now it's your turn to be the word collector! Grab your reading book and find three words that you don't know. For each of those words, you'll fill out your journal completely, just like we practiced: write the word, the sentence you found it in, your best guess of what it means, the real definition from the dictionary, a sentence you create, and a drawing. Take your time and make it look super neat!

slides.text: Your vocabulary journal will grow all year! Try to add at least 2 new words each week. The more words you know, the more you can understand and express. Keep your journal with you when you read!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child use context clues to make a reasonable guess about a word's meaning and create a complete vocabulary entry?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the word treasures you've collected in your journal! You've learned how to be a super word detective and find the meaning of new words all by yourself. Keep adding new words to your journal every week, and soon you'll have the biggest and best word collection ever, which will make you an even more amazing reader and writer!

parent_notes: The vocabulary journal becomes a personalized reference that grows with the child. Context clues are a critical reading strategy — encourage the child to guess before looking up. Research shows that words learned in context are retained better than words memorized from lists. Aim for quality entries over quantity. Review the journal weekly to reinforce learned words.

title: Adding Like Fractions — Practice and Problem Solving
description: Students practice adding fractions with like denominators, moving from fraction insets to pictorial models to abstract equations. They solve word problems involving fraction addition.
instructions:
1. Warm up: review adding like fractions with insets.
2. Transition to pictorial: draw fraction circles, shade, and add.
3. Transition to abstract: write and solve equations without pictures.
4. Introduce word problems: 'Maria ate 2/6 of the pizza. Her brother ate 3/6. How much did they eat together?'
5. The child creates their own word problem.
6. Practice a set of mixed problems.

slides.heading: Adding Fractions Practice
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our title slide, showing us that today we're going to practice adding fractions. We'll start with some hands-on pieces and then move to drawing and solving problems with just numbers, and even some fun word problems!

slides.setup_instructions: Keep fraction insets accessible but encourage pictorial and abstract work. Write word problems on cards. Open math journal to a fresh page.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our supplies ready for today's fraction adventure! We'll need our fraction insets to help us check our work, our math journal and a pencil for writing and drawing, and some colored pencils to make our pictures super clear. We also have some word problem cards ready for us to solve.

slides.text: Warm up with the insets: 1/5 + 2/5 = ? Place the pieces, count, and confirm: 3/5. Now draw it: draw a circle divided into 5 parts, shade 1, then shade 2 more. Total shaded: 3/5.
slides.mascot_explanation: This first step is like a warm-up, using those cool fraction pieces. It asks us to add 1/5 and 2/5. First, you'll find the pieces that show 1/5 and 2/5, put them together, and see that you have 3/5. Then, you'll draw a circle, divide it into 5 equal parts, shade one part for 1/5, and then shade two more parts for the 2/5, showing that you have 3 shaded parts total.

slides.text: Now try without pictures: 2/8 + 3/8 = ? The denominators are the same (8), so add the numerators: 2 + 3 = 5. Answer: 5/8. Check with the inset if you want!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to try adding fractions using just numbers, which is called the abstract way. We're looking at 2/8 + 3/8. Since both fractions have the same bottom number (the denominator, 8), we just need to add the top numbers (the numerators), 2 plus 3, which equals 5. So, 2/8 + 3/8 is 5/8! You can use your fraction insets to check if you like.

slides.text: Word problem: 'Maria ate 2/6 of the pizza. Her brother ate 3/6. How much pizza did they eat together?' Draw the pizza, shade Maria's slices, shade her brother's slices. 2/6 + 3/6 = 5/6.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a word problem about pizza! Maria ate 2/6 of a pizza, and her brother ate 3/6. We need to figure out how much they ate altogether. Imagine a pizza cut into 6 slices; you'll color 2 slices for Maria and 3 more for her brother. When you count them all up, you'll see they ate 5/6 of the pizza together.

slides.prompt: Solve these problems in your math journal, showing your work with pictures and equations: 1) 3/8 + 2/8 = ? 2) 1/5 + 3/5 = ? 3) 4/10 + 5/10 = ? 4) Word problem: 'Dad drank 1/4 of the juice. Mom drank 2/4. How much did they drink?' 5) Create your own fraction word problem and solve it!
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for some fun practice! In your math journal, you'll solve these problems. For the first few, just add the fractions like we've been doing. Then, there's a word problem about juice that you'll draw out and solve. The very last one is super creative – you get to make up your *own* fraction word problem and solve it!

slides.text: You can now add fractions three ways: with fraction pieces, with pictures, and with numbers! The rule is simple: same denominator, add the numerators. Tomorrow we will explore what happens when the sum is more than one whole!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child add like fractions using pictures and equations, and solve a fraction word problem?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You learned how to add fractions in so many ways: using those cool pieces, drawing them out, and even just using numbers. Remember, when the bottom numbers are the same, you just add the top numbers together. Tomorrow, we'll see what happens when we add enough pieces to make more than one whole pizza!

parent_notes: The progression from concrete (insets) to pictorial (drawings) to abstract (equations) mirrors the Montessori approach to all math learning. Do not rush past the pictorial stage — drawing fractions builds deep understanding. Word problems apply fraction skills to real life. When the child creates their own problem, they demonstrate the highest level of understanding.

title: Ancient Egypt — Pharaohs and the Double Crown
description: Students learn about the pharaohs as god-kings of Egypt, the unification of Upper and Lower Egypt, and the significance of the double crown (pschent). They study notable pharaohs including Narmer, Khufu, and Hatshepsut.
instructions:
1. Explain the role of the pharaoh: king, religious leader, and living god.
2. Tell the story of King Narmer unifying Upper and Lower Egypt around 3100 BCE.
3. Show the crowns: White Crown of Upper Egypt, Red Crown of Lower Egypt, Double Crown of unified Egypt.
4. Introduce notable pharaohs: Khufu (built Great Pyramid), Hatshepsut (female pharaoh), Tutankhamun (boy king).
5. The child draws the three crowns and creates pharaoh biography cards.
6. Add pharaoh dates to the timeline.

slides.heading: The Pharaohs
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the title slide for our adventure into Ancient Egypt! It's called "The Pharaohs" and tells us they were like super-rulers, called "God-Kings." We're going to learn all about the powerful people who ruled Egypt a super long time ago.

items: Pictures of the White Crown, Red Crown, and Double Crown
Photos or illustrations of famous pharaohs
Drawing paper, colored pencils, gold crayon/marker
slides.setup_instructions: Display crown images prominently. Prepare pharaoh reference information. Have index cards and the timeline ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this is our materials station for today! We've got pictures of three really important Egyptian crowns that you'll get to see. We also have photos of some famous pharaohs, some special index cards for making fact cards, drawing paper, colorful pencils, and a gold crayon or marker to make things shiny, plus our history timeline.

slides.text: The pharaoh was not just a king — the Egyptians believed the pharaoh was a living god! The pharaoh owned all the land, commanded the army, and was the head of the religion. The word 'pharaoh' means 'great house.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide explains who the pharaoh was. Imagine the most important person in the whole country, who everyone listened to, and who people thought was like a god on Earth! That was the pharaoh. They owned everything and were in charge of the army and the religion, and their title actually meant "great house."

slides.text: Around 3100 BCE, King Narmer united Upper Egypt (the south, with the White Crown shaped like a bowling pin) and Lower Egypt (the north, with the flat Red Crown). He combined them into the Double Crown — the pschent — showing he ruled all of Egypt.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for a cool story about how Egypt became one big country! A long, long time ago, there were two parts of Egypt, the south and the north, each with its own crown. Then, a king named Narmer brought them together and wore a brand new crown, the Double Crown, to show he was the ruler of *all* of Egypt.

slides.text: Let us meet some famous pharaohs: Khufu built the Great Pyramid at Giza. Hatshepsut was a powerful female pharaoh who wore a false beard! Tutankhamun became pharaoh at age 9. His tomb was found full of golden treasures in 1922.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to meet some of the most famous pharaohs! There was Khufu, who built the giant Great Pyramid we've all heard of. Then there was Hatshepsut, a queen who ruled like a king and even wore a fake beard! And don't forget Tutankhamun, who became king when he was just a kid and whose tomb was found filled with amazing treasures.

slides.prompt: Draw and color the three Egyptian crowns: White Crown, Red Crown, and Double Crown. Then create biography cards for 3 pharaohs: on each card write the pharaoh's name, when they ruled, what they are famous for, and draw their portrait in Egyptian style.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be the artist and historian! First, grab your paper and colored pencils to draw the three crowns you saw earlier – the White, the Red, and the Double Crown. Then, use your index cards to make little biography cards for three pharaohs, writing down their name, when they ruled, and what they did, and drawing a picture of them.

slides.text: The pharaohs ruled Egypt for over 3,000 years — that is longer than the time from Julius Caesar to today! Next time, we will explore the greatest monuments the pharaohs built: the pyramids.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain the pharaoh's role, identify the three crowns, and name at least 2 famous pharaohs with key facts?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we learned so much about the pharaohs today! You drew the crowns and made awesome biography cards for some super famous rulers. Can you believe they ruled Egypt for over 3,000 years? Next time, we'll discover the incredible pyramids they built!

parent_notes: Children are fascinated by pharaohs, especially Tutankhamun (a child king!) and Hatshepsut (she broke gender barriers 3,500 years ago). The crown symbolism is a great way to teach about political unification. If the child is interested, the Narmer Palette is one of the oldest historical documents — look up images online together.

title: Egyptian Culture — Daily Life Along the Nile
description: Students explore daily life in Ancient Egypt: what people ate, wore, and did for fun. They compare Egyptian daily life to their own and discover surprising similarities and differences.
instructions:
1. Describe a day in the life of an Egyptian child.
2. Food: bread, beer, fish, vegetables, dates, and figs.
3. Clothing: linen garments, sandals, jewelry and makeup for everyone.
4. Fun: board games (Senet), swimming, hunting, festivals.
5. The child creates a Venn diagram comparing their daily life to an Egyptian child's.
6. Play a round of Senet (or a simplified version).

slides.heading: Life in Ancient Egypt
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like the cover of a book, showing us what our adventure is all about! It tells us we're going to be learning about what life was like for people living a super long time ago in a place called Ancient Egypt, right by a big river called the Nile. Think of it like peeking into a time machine to see how kids just like you lived way back then!

items: Pictures or reference book showing Egyptian daily life
Materials for simple Senet game (grid drawn on paper, coins as pieces, popsicle sticks as dice)
slides.setup_instructions: Display daily life images. Draw a Venn diagram on large paper (labeled 'Ancient Egypt' and 'My Life' with 'Both' in the middle). Prepare a simple Senet board.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this is our treasure chest for today's adventure! We've got pictures or a book so we can see what Ancient Egypt looked like, paper for making a special chart, and some cool stuff to make a game called Senet – like checkers, but Egyptian style! We also need a journal and some colorful pencils to draw what we learn. Make sure you have a grown-up help you gather everything so we're ready to explore!

slides.text: Imagine you are a child in Ancient Egypt. You wake up in a mud-brick house, eat bread and figs for breakfast, put on a linen tunic and sandals. If you are from a rich family, you go to school to learn hieroglyphics. If not, you help with farming or a trade.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to imagine we're actually living in Ancient Egypt! Picture yourself waking up in a house made of sun-dried mud, like a giant LEGO brick house. You'd eat yummy things like bread and sweet figs for breakfast, then put on simple clothes made of a soft material called linen, and maybe some sandals. If your family was wealthy, you might go to school to learn a cool secret code called hieroglyphics, but if not, you'd help out with growing food or making things.

slides.text: Egyptian children played games! Senet was the most popular board game — pharaohs and common people both loved it. Children also swam in the Nile, played with balls and dolls, and had pets like dogs, cats, and monkeys!
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for playtime, Egyptian style! Kids back then loved games, and Senet was their favorite board game – even the kings and queens played it! They also loved splashing in the Nile River, playing with balls and dolls, and even had pets like cats and monkeys. It sounds like they knew how to have fun, just like you do!

slides.text: Surprising facts: Egyptians wore eye makeup for protection from the sun and insects. Both men and women wore jewelry. They brushed their teeth with a paste made from eggshells and ox hooves! They invented some of the first board games.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here are some super neat facts about Ancient Egyptians! Did you know they wore makeup around their eyes, not just to look fancy, but to protect them from the bright sun and pesky bugs? Both boys and girls, and even grown-ups, wore shiny jewelry, and they even cleaned their teeth with a special paste made from things like eggshells! It's amazing how clever they were, inventing things like board games that we still play today.

slides.prompt: Complete the Venn diagram comparing your daily life with an Egyptian child's life. Include at least 5 items in each section. Then try a game of Senet! In your journal, write: 'If I lived in Ancient Egypt, I would...' (at least 5 sentences).
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be a super detective! We're going to make a special chart called a Venn diagram, which is like a big circle with two overlapping parts. You'll draw pictures or write words about your own life in one part, and what we learned about an Egyptian child's life in the other, and then see what's the same in the middle. After that, we'll play our Senet game, and then in your journal, you'll write about what you'd do if you lived in Ancient Egypt. You've got this!

slides.text: People 4,000 years ago were not so different from us! They loved their families, played games, ate good food, and had fun. Understanding daily life helps us connect with people across time.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe 3 aspects of Egyptian daily life and identify both similarities and differences with their own life?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at everything we learned! We discovered that even though Egyptians lived thousands of years ago, they were a lot like us – they loved their families, played games, and had fun. It's like finding out you have cousins you never knew you had, but they live way, way back in time! You can now tell me three cool things about Egyptian life and how it's like or different from yours. High five!

parent_notes: Daily life topics make ancient history relatable and engaging. The Venn diagram develops compare/contrast thinking. A simplified Senet game can be made with a 3x10 grid, coins, and popsicle sticks (marked on one side for 'casting'). The real rules are debated by historians, so any version is fine. Emphasize connections between then and now rather than exoticism.

title: Read Aloud — The Pyramids: How and Why
description: Continue the Egypt read-aloud with a chapter on the pyramids. Students learn about the construction of the Great Pyramid and discuss the engineering marvels of the ancient world.
instructions:
1. Review what we read last time about Egypt.
2. Read the chapter about pyramids aloud.
3. Discuss: How did they build pyramids without modern machines?
4. Talk about the purpose: tombs for pharaohs, filled with treasures for the afterlife.
5. The child draws the Great Pyramid and writes 5 facts about it.
6. Add new vocabulary words to the vocabulary journal.

slides.heading: The Pyramids
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our new chapter! It tells us we're going to learn all about the amazing pyramids, and how they were like super cool buildings that real scientists and builders worked on a long, long time ago. Isn't it neat that we get to explore how they built such giant things?

slides.setup_instructions: Bookmark the pyramid chapter. Have both journals ready. Display a picture of the Great Pyramid if possible.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this part, we need a few things to help us learn. We've got our Egypt book to read from, and two special notebooks: one for writing down new words and one for drawing and writing facts. You'll also need a pencil and some colored pencils for our drawing later. Go grab all of those with a grown-up so we're ready to go!

slides.text: Quick review: What have we learned about Egypt so far? The Nile, the pharaohs, the crowns. Today we read about the most famous structures in the world — the pyramids!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is like a little warm-up before we dive into the pyramids. Remember how we talked about the big river, the Nile, and the kings called pharaohs? Well, today we're going to learn about the most famous things Egyptians ever built – the giant pyramids! Get ready to be amazed by them.

slides.text: Read the pyramid chapter aloud. Pause to marvel: 'The Great Pyramid at Giza used over 2 million stone blocks, each weighing as much as a car! It took about 20 years and thousands of workers to build.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time for the exciting part – reading about the pyramids! As we read, I want you to listen closely, especially when it talks about how HUGE they are. Imagine building something with more than 2 million giant stone blocks, each one as heavy as a car! It took them so, so long, kind of like building the biggest LEGO tower ever, but way harder.

slides.text: After reading, discuss: 'Why did the Egyptians build pyramids? (Tombs for pharaohs, to protect their body and treasures for the afterlife.) How do you think they moved those enormous stones without trucks or cranes?'
slides.mascot_explanation: After we finish reading, we'll chat about some super interesting questions. We'll think about *why* they built these massive pyramids – were they houses, or something else? And we'll really wonder, how did they move those gigantic stones without any trucks or cranes like we have today? It's a big mystery!

slides.prompt: Draw the Great Pyramid with a cross-section showing the chambers inside. Write 5 amazing facts about the pyramids from today's reading. Add 3 new vocabulary words to your vocabulary journal (e.g., sarcophagus, pharaoh, monument).
slides.mascot_explanation: This is your chance to show off what you learned! You get to draw the Great Pyramid, and even draw secret rooms inside it, like a treasure map. Then, write down five cool things you remember about them from our reading. And don't forget to add three new words to your special word notebook to remember them.

slides.text: The pyramids are the only ancient wonder of the world still standing! They have survived for over 4,500 years. What does that tell you about Egyptian engineering?
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain why pyramids were built and state at least 3 facts about their construction?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at what you did! You learned about the pyramids, drew one, and remembered so many facts! It's amazing that these giant structures are still standing after thousands and thousands of years, isn't it? That really shows how incredibly smart the ancient Egyptians were at building things.

parent_notes: The pyramids captivate children's imaginations. The scale is hard to grasp — compare the Great Pyramid's height (481 feet) to buildings the child knows. The construction methods are still debated by historians, which is an opportunity to discuss how historians think and investigate. If possible, watch a short documentary clip about pyramid construction.

title: Prefix Review — Word Detective Activity
description: Students review all four prefixes (un-, re-, pre-, dis-) through a word detective activity where they find prefixed words in a text and determine their meanings.
instructions:
1. Review all four prefixes and their meanings.
2. Provide a passage containing words with all four prefixes.
3. The child highlights or circles every word with a prefix.
4. For each word, identify the prefix, base word, and meaning.
5. Create a prefix poster or reference card.
6. Quiz game: parent says a base word, child adds the correct prefix.

slides.heading: Prefix Word Detective
slides.mascot_explanation: Welcome, Word Detective! This slide is like your secret mission briefing. We're going to be looking for special word parts called prefixes – those little bits at the beginning of words like 'un-', 're-', 'pre-', and 'dis-'. Think of yourself as a super sleuth, ready to uncover the hidden meanings in words!

items: Prepared passage with 12-15 prefix words embedded
Poster board or large card stock
slides.setup_instructions: Write or print a passage that naturally includes words with all four prefixes. Prepare highlighters in 4 distinct colors. Have poster materials ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, let's get our detective gear ready! You'll need that story I prepared, which has lots of words with our special prefixes. Then, grab those four colored highlighters – each color is for a different prefix, so we can keep them super organized. We also need poster board, markers, and your vocabulary journal to record our findings.

slides.text: You are a Word Detective! Your mission: find every word in this passage that has a prefix. Use a different color for each prefix: yellow for un-, green for re-, blue for pre-, pink for dis-.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, Detective, this is your first clue! You're going to read through the story and become a word finder. Your job is to spot every word that starts with 'un-', 're-', 'pre-', or 'dis-'. Use yellow for 'un-', green for 're-', blue for 'pre-', and pink for 'dis-' to highlight them.

slides.text: For each word you find, write it in your journal and break it apart: PREFIX + BASE WORD = NEW MEANING. Example: un + happy = unhappy (not happy). re + build = rebuild (build again).
slides.mascot_explanation: Now that you've found the words, let's crack the code! In your journal, write down each word you highlighted. Then, like a puzzle, break it into its prefix and its base word – that's the main part of the word. Next to it, write down what the new word means because of the prefix. For example, 'un-' means 'not', so 'unhappy' means 'not happy'!

slides.text: Now create a Prefix Reference Poster. Divide it into 4 sections. For each prefix, write: the prefix, its meaning, and 5 example words. Illustrate with drawings that show the meaning change.
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to make a super cool reference poster to show off what you know! We'll divide your poster into four parts, one for each prefix. For each prefix, write it down, explain what it means, and then write five words that use it. You can even draw a little picture for each word to show how the prefix changes the meaning!

slides.prompt: Complete the word detective passage, then create your Prefix Reference Poster. Finally, play the prefix quiz: your parent says a base word and a meaning clue, you name the correct prefix. Score 10 points for each correct answer!
slides.mascot_explanation: You're doing great, Detective! Now it's time to put all your detective skills to work. Finish finding and breaking down those words in the passage and get your amazing Prefix Reference Poster finished. Then, we'll play a fun game where I give you a base word, and you have to add the correct prefix to make a new word. You can earn points for every right answer!

slides.text: You are a prefix expert! Hang your poster where you can see it while reading. Whenever you encounter a word with a prefix, you can decode its meaning. Next week, we will learn suffixes — letters added to the END of words.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify prefixed words in text, separate prefix from base word, and explain the meaning change for all 4 prefixes?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you are a true Prefix Expert! Look at that amazing poster you made – it's going to be so helpful for understanding new words. Remember, when you see a prefix, you already know part of the word's meaning. Soon we'll learn about suffixes, which are word parts that go on the *end* of words!

parent_notes: The word detective activity trains the child to actively look for word parts while reading — a critical decoding strategy. For the passage, you can use text from their current reading book or write one specifically. The poster becomes a reference tool for independent reading. The quiz game format makes review fun and builds automaticity.

title: Fractions of a Set — Multi-Step Problems
