description: Students extend their understanding of fractions of a set to multi-step problems: finding non-unit fractions of sets (2/3 of 15) and solving real-world fraction problems.
instructions:
1. Review finding 1/3 of a number (divide into 3 groups, take 1).
2. Extend to 2/3 of a number (divide into 3 groups, take 2).
3. Practice: 2/3 of 15, 3/4 of 20, 2/5 of 25.
4. Solve word problems: 'There are 24 students. 3/4 brought lunch. How many brought lunch?'
5. The child creates real-world problems for a partner.
6. Connect to multiplication: 3/4 of 20 = 3 × (20 ÷ 4) = 3 × 5 = 15.

slides.heading: Fractions of a Set
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our lesson title slide! It tells us we're going to become super-duper fraction experts today, especially with fractions that have bigger numbers on top, like 2/3 or 3/4. We'll learn how to figure out what part of a group those fractions make up.

slides.setup_instructions: Count out sets of counters in advance: 15, 20, 25, 24, 30. Have sorting cups ready. Write word problems on cards.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our tools ready for some fraction fun! We need counters, which are like little pretend objects to help us count, and sorting cups to keep our groups neat. Your math journal and pencil are for writing down your awesome discoveries, and the word problem cards have fun challenges for us. Make sure you have all these things with you!

slides.text: Yesterday we found 1/3 of a set. Today we will find 2/3! Start with 15 counters. To find 2/3 of 15: first divide 15 into 3 equal groups (5 in each). For 2/3, take 2 of those groups: 5 + 5 = 10. So 2/3 of 15 = 10.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is like building on what we learned yesterday. Remember how we found 1/3 of a group? Now we're going to find 2/3! So, if you have 15 counters, you'll first split them into 3 equal piles – imagine sharing them equally among 3 friends. Then, instead of taking just one pile, you'll take two of those piles to make your 2/3.

slides.text: Try 3/4 of 20: Divide 20 into 4 groups (5 each). Take 3 groups: 5 + 5 + 5 = 15. So 3/4 of 20 = 15. The denominator tells you how many groups, the numerator tells you how many groups to take.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're trying a different fraction, 3/4, with 20 counters. Think about sharing those 20 counters into 4 equal groups, like putting them into 4 separate bowls. Since we want 3/4, we'll count up the counters in 3 of those bowls. The bottom number (the denominator) always tells us how many total groups to make, and the top number (the numerator) tells us how many groups to grab!

slides.text: Word problem: 'There are 24 crayons. 2/6 are blue. How many blue crayons?' Divide 24 into 6 groups (4 each). Take 2 groups: 4 + 4 = 8 blue crayons. Draw it to prove it!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a real-world math puzzle! Imagine you have 24 crayons, and the problem says 2/6 of them are blue. To solve it, you’d first divide your 24 crayons into 6 equal groups. Then, because the fraction is 2/6, you'd count up the crayons in just 2 of those groups to find out how many blue ones there are. Drawing it out can help you see it clearly!

slides.prompt: Solve with counters and record in your journal: 1) 2/3 of 18, 2) 3/4 of 16, 3) 2/5 of 25, 4) 5/6 of 24, 5) Word problem: 'A baker made 20 cookies. 3/5 had chocolate chips. How many chocolate chip cookies?' 6) Create your own word problem for a friend to solve.
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to put on your thinking caps and be math detectives! You'll use your counters to solve a few fraction puzzles, like finding 2/3 of 18. After you solve them, you get to be the teacher and create your very own word problem for a friend to solve – how cool is that? Don't forget to write down your answers in your journal.

slides.text: You can find ANY fraction of a set: divide into groups (denominator), then take the right number of groups (numerator). This is one of the most useful math skills in real life!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child find non-unit fractions of a set (e.g., 2/3, 3/4) and solve a word problem involving fractions of a set?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You learned how to find parts of a group using fractions, even when the top number is bigger than one. You figured out how to divide things up and then take the right amount, which is a super important skill for lots of things in life, not just math class! You're a fraction whiz!

parent_notes: Finding non-unit fractions of a set is a significant step up from unit fractions. The two-step process (divide, then multiply) is the foundation for fraction multiplication in later grades. Real-world connections are everywhere: '3/4 of the class is here today,' 'You ate 2/5 of the pizza.' Look for fraction-of-a-set situations in daily life.

title: Mammals — Adaptations by Habitat
description: Students explore how mammals have adapted to different habitats: Arctic mammals have thick fur and blubber, desert mammals are nocturnal with large ears, aquatic mammals have streamlined bodies and blowholes.
instructions:
1. Review: mammals live in every habitat on Earth.
2. Present Arctic adaptations: thick fur, blubber, white coloring (polar bears, Arctic foxes).
3. Present desert adaptations: nocturnal behavior, large ears for cooling, water conservation (camels, fennec foxes).
4. Present aquatic adaptations: streamlined bodies, flippers, blowholes (whales, dolphins, seals).
5. The child creates an adaptation chart in their science journal.
6. Match animal pictures to their habitat and explain the adaptations.

slides.heading: Mammal Adaptations
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page of our adventure! It tells us we're going to learn all about "Mammal Adaptations" and how they are super survivors in all sorts of places. Get ready to discover how animals like bears, foxes, and whales are perfectly built for where they live!

items: Animal picture cards showing various mammals in their habitats
4 habitat cards: Arctic, Desert, Ocean, Forest
Reference books or printed adaptation information
slides.setup_instructions: Set out the 4 habitat cards as sorting stations. Shuffle animal picture cards. Open science journal to a new 'Adaptations' page.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool stuff we need for our mammal investigation. We have picture cards of animals, four big cards showing different homes like the snowy Arctic and hot Desert, a science journal for drawing, and some colored pencils. You'll also need some books or printed info to help us learn about the animals, so grab all those things with a grown-up!

slides.text: Mammals live everywhere — from freezing Arctic ice to scorching deserts, from deep oceans to high mountains. How do they survive such different environments? Through adaptations — special features that help them survive.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is like the big idea of our lesson! It's telling us that mammals, like puppies and kitties and even us, live all over the Earth, in places that are super hot, super cold, or even underwater. The secret to how they stay alive in these tough spots is called "adaptations," which are special body parts or behaviors that help them out.

slides.text: Arctic mammals like polar bears have thick fur and a layer of blubber (fat) to stay warm. Their white color helps them hide in the snow. Desert mammals like fennec foxes have HUGE ears — not for hearing, but to release heat and cool down! Camels store fat in their humps for energy.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're talking about animals that live where it's freezing cold, like the Arctic! See how polar bears have super thick fur and a layer of fat called blubber? That keeps them toasty warm, and their white fur is like a camouflage costume so they can sneak up on their dinner in the snow. Then, in the super hot desert, animals like fennec foxes have giant ears that help them let off extra heat, kind of like a built-in fan!

slides.text: Ocean mammals like whales have streamlined bodies for swimming, flippers instead of legs, and blowholes to breathe at the surface. Forest mammals like monkeys have grasping hands and tails for climbing trees.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here we're looking at mammals who live in the water and in forests. Ocean mammals like dolphins have smooth, sleek bodies perfect for gliding through the water, and they breathe through a hole on top of their head called a blowhole. Forest critters like monkeys have hands and tails that are amazing for swinging through the trees, like furry acrobats!

slides.prompt: Create an Adaptation Chart in your science journal with 4 habitat columns. For each habitat, list 3 mammals, draw one, and explain at least 2 adaptations that help it survive. Challenge: find a mammal that can live in more than one habitat!
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to become adaptation detectives in your science journal! You'll make a chart with columns for each habitat, then pick three animals for each place, draw one, and write down two special things about them that help them survive there. It's like creating your own animal survival guide!

slides.text: Adaptations show how amazing evolution is — over millions of years, mammals developed incredible features to survive. Humans are mammals too! What adaptations do we have? (Think: our big brains, our ability to sweat, our opposable thumbs.)
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain at least 2 adaptations for mammals in 3 different habitats and state why each adaptation is helpful?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you've done an amazing job learning about how animals have special skills to live in different places! We learned that mammals have all sorts of cool features, like thick fur or big ears, that help them survive. And guess what? Humans are mammals too, so think about what makes *us* special survivors!

parent_notes: Adaptations are a core concept in biology. The key is connecting structure to function: 'Why does the fennec fox have big ears? Because large ears release more heat, keeping the fox cool in the desert.' This cause-and-effect thinking is essential scientific reasoning. If the child is interested, explore convergent evolution — how unrelated animals in similar habitats develop similar adaptations.

title: Triangles — Classification by Sides and Angles
description: Students learn to classify triangles by their sides (equilateral, isosceles, scalene) and by their angles (right, acute, obtuse) using the Montessori geometry cabinet and constructive triangles.
instructions:
1. Present the three triangle types by sides: equilateral (all equal), isosceles (two equal), scalene (none equal).
2. Examine triangles from the geometry cabinet.
3. Present classification by angles: right (has a 90° angle), acute (all angles less than 90°), obtuse (one angle greater than 90°).
4. The child sorts a collection of triangles by both characteristics.
5. Build triangles with geometry sticks.
6. Create a triangle classification poster.

slides.heading: Triangles
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure! It tells us we're going to learn all about triangles and how we can sort them into different groups based on how their sides are shaped and how their corners look. It's like learning the secret code for different kinds of triangles!

items: Geometry cabinet (triangle drawer) or triangle cutouts
slides.setup_instructions: Lay out the triangle drawer from the geometry cabinet. Set out constructive triangles and geometry sticks. Prepare a classification chart template.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our explorer tools ready! We've got a special drawer with lots of different triangles in it – that's our geometry cabinet, and each one is a puzzle piece for us. We also have sticks to build our own triangles and a special tool called a protractor to measure the corners, like a super-accurate ruler for angles. We'll also need our math journal and some colored pencils to draw what we discover!

slides.text: All triangles have 3 sides and 3 angles, but they come in different types! By SIDES: Equilateral — all 3 sides are equal (like an even triangle). Isosceles — exactly 2 sides are equal. Scalene — no sides are equal (all different lengths).
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is teaching us how to sort triangles just by looking at their sides. Imagine you have three sticks to make a triangle. If all three sticks are the exact same length, it's called equilateral – like a perfectly balanced triangle. If two sticks are the same length and one is different, it's isosceles, and if all three sticks are different lengths, we call it scalene.

slides.text: We can also classify by ANGLES: Acute triangle — all 3 angles are less than 90° (all pointy). Right triangle — has exactly one 90° angle (like a corner). Obtuse triangle — has one angle greater than 90° (one wide angle).
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, we're going to learn how to sort triangles by looking at their angles, which are the corners! If all three corners are small and pointy, like the tip of a pencil, it's an acute triangle. If one corner is perfectly square, like the corner of a book or a door, that's a right triangle. And if one corner is wide and open, like a sleepy yawn, that's an obtuse triangle.

slides.text: A triangle can be classified BOTH ways! An 'isosceles right triangle' has 2 equal sides AND a right angle. Use the geometry sticks to build one of each type. Measure the angles with a protractor.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is super cool because it tells us triangles can be described in BOTH ways at the same time! So, a triangle could have two sides that are the same length AND a square corner – that's called an isosceles right triangle. We'll use our sticks to build different kinds and our protractor to check those angles, just like real scientists!

slides.prompt: In your math journal, create a Triangle Classification page. Draw and label: equilateral, isosceles, and scalene triangles. Draw and label: acute, right, and obtuse triangles. Build each type with geometry sticks and measure the angles. Challenge: can you make a right scalene triangle?
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to become triangle artists and builders! In your math journal, you'll draw examples of equilateral, isosceles, and scalene triangles, and also acute, right, and obtuse ones, labeling each one so you remember its name. Then, use your geometry sticks to build them and measure their angles to be sure. Can you try to build a triangle with no equal sides but one square corner? That’s a tricky challenge!

slides.text: Triangles are the strongest shape in construction — bridges, roofs, and towers all use triangles! Now you can look at any triangle and name its type by sides and angles. You are a triangle expert!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child classify triangles by both sides (equilateral, isosceles, scalene) and angles (acute, right, obtuse)?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You learned that triangles are super strong, used in bridges and buildings! You can now look at any triangle and tell me if its sides are all the same, if two are the same, or if they're all different, and you can also tell me if its corners are pointy, square, or wide. You are officially a triangle classification expert!

parent_notes: Triangle classification involves dual categorization, which is a higher-order thinking skill. The geometry cabinet makes this concrete — the child can feel the differences between triangle types. Building with geometry sticks reinforces understanding through construction. If the child enjoys this, encourage finding triangles in architecture and nature (snowflakes, honeycombs, bridges).

title: Egyptian Cartouche — Name in Hieroglyphics
description: Students create a cartouche (an oval nameplate used by pharaohs) with their name written in hieroglyphics. This connects art, history, and the Great Lesson on Writing.
instructions:
1. Explain what a cartouche is: a protective oval containing a pharaoh's name in hieroglyphics.
2. Show the hieroglyphic alphabet — each symbol represents a sound.
3. The child translates their name into hieroglyphic symbols.
4. Draw an oval cartouche shape on art paper.
5. Write their name in hieroglyphics inside the cartouche.
6. Decorate with Egyptian colors and symbols.
materials_needed: Gold and colored markers or paint

slides.heading: My Egyptian Cartouche
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our super cool project! It tells us we're going to make our very own "cartouche," which is like a special nameplate, and we'll write our names using ancient Egyptian pictures called hieroglyphics. Isn't it exciting to think we'll be writing like kings and queens from a long, long time ago?

items: Sturdy art paper or card stock
slides.setup_instructions: Print a hieroglyphic alphabet chart. Display examples of real cartouches from pharaoh tombs. Cut art paper into elongated oval shapes or let children draw their own.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, let's gather our treasures for this adventure! We've got a chart that shows us all the cool Egyptian picture letters – that's our hieroglyphic alphabet. We also need some strong paper, maybe already cut into an oval shape, or we can draw our own. Then we'll need shiny gold paint or a marker, and other colors for decorating, plus some pictures of real Egyptian cartouches to give us ideas. Go grab everything with a grown-up, and let's get ready to create!

slides.text: A cartouche is an oval frame that held a pharaoh's name in hieroglyphics. The oval shape was like a rope tied in a loop — it meant protection. Only royal names were written inside cartouches.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, what exactly is a cartouche? Imagine a special oval shape, kind of like a fancy loop of rope. The ancient Egyptians, especially their kings and queens called pharaohs, used this oval shape to protect their names. It was a very important way to write their royal names, and now we get to learn about it!

slides.text: Hieroglyphics used pictures for sounds. An owl = the 'm' sound. A reed = 'i.' A hand = 'd.' Use the alphabet chart to find the symbol for each letter of your name.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide shows us how the Egyptians wrote words. Instead of letters like we have, they used pictures to make sounds! For example, a picture of an owl might mean the 'm' sound, and a hand might mean the 'd' sound. We're going to use our alphabet chart to find the right picture for each letter in our own name.

slides.text: Draw a large oval (cartouche shape) on your paper. Carefully draw each hieroglyphic symbol for the letters of your name inside the oval, one below the other like the Egyptians did.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the fun part: drawing! First, take your paper and draw a big, beautiful oval shape – that's your cartouche. Inside that oval, you're going to carefully draw the special Egyptian picture symbols for each letter of your name, stacking them up one by one, just like the ancient Egyptians did.

slides.prompt: Create your personal cartouche: draw the oval frame, write your name in hieroglyphics inside it, paint or color the background gold, and add Egyptian decorative elements around the border (lotus flowers, scarab beetles, ankh symbols).
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to make some magic! This is where you get to be the artist and the ancient scribe. Draw that oval frame, then carefully write your name inside using those cool hieroglyphic symbols you found. After that, fill the background with shiny gold paint or marker, and then you can add awesome Egyptian designs like flowers or beetles around the edges!

slides.text: You have written your name the way an Egyptian pharaoh would! Hieroglyphics were used for over 3,000 years until people forgot how to read them. It took the Rosetta Stone to unlock the secret. We will learn about that next week!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child translate at least 3 letters of their name into hieroglyphic symbols and explain what a cartouche is?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at what you've done! You've created your very own cartouche and written your name in hieroglyphics, just like a pharaoh from ancient Egypt. That's amazing because hieroglyphics were a secret code for thousands of years until people figured them out. Next time, we'll discover how they unlocked that secret!

parent_notes: This is one of the most popular Montessori Egypt activities. Hieroglyphic alphabet charts are readily available online — search 'hieroglyphic alphabet for kids.' The connection between the Great Lesson on Writing and hieroglyphics reinforces the cosmic narrative. If the child is motivated, they can write messages in hieroglyphics to family members. Display the cartouche prominently.

title: Prefix Application — Reading with Prefix Awareness
description: Students apply their prefix knowledge while reading independently, marking and decoding prefixed words they encounter. This transfers word study skills to authentic reading.
instructions:
1. Review the 4 prefixes one more time.
2. The child reads independently for 15-20 minutes from their current book.
3. As they read, they use sticky notes to flag words with prefixes.
4. After reading, record each flagged word in the vocabulary journal.
5. Break each word into prefix + base word and define it.
6. Write a reading response paragraph about the chapter.

slides.heading: Reading with Prefix Power
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title for our super fun reading adventure today! It's called "Reading with Prefix Power," and it means we're going to use our knowledge of prefixes to become "Word Detectives" while we read. Get ready to use your super smart brain to find hidden word parts!

items: Small sticky notes or sticky flags
Prefix reference poster from earlier this week
slides.setup_instructions: Set up a comfortable reading spot. Provide sticky notes and have the vocabulary journal nearby. Post the prefix poster where the child can see it while reading.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our detective gear ready! You'll need your own book to read, which is like your case file for today. We also have these little sticky notes, which are perfect for marking clues – those are our prefix words! And don't forget your vocabulary journal and a pencil to write down what you discover, plus that poster with the prefixes we learned about to help you out.

slides.text: Quick prefix review: un- means not/opposite, re- means again, pre- means before, dis- means not/apart. Today you will be a Word Detective while reading your book!
slides.mascot_explanation: Before we become word detectives, let's quickly remember our secret codes, our prefixes! We have 'un-' which means not or the opposite, like 'unhappy' means not happy. Then there's 're-' which means 'again', like 'redo' means to do it again. 'Pre-' means 'before', so 'preview' is looking before. And 'dis-' means 'not' or 'apart', like 'disagree' means not agreeing.

slides.text: As you read, whenever you spot a word with one of our four prefixes, put a tiny sticky note next to it. Keep reading — do not stop to write yet. Just flag the words and keep going.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the exciting part of being a word detective! As you read your book, I want you to keep your eyes peeled for words that start with those prefixes we just reviewed. When you find one, don't stop reading or try to figure it out just yet – just pop a sticky note right next to it to mark it as a clue.

slides.text: After reading, go back to your flagged words. In your vocabulary journal, write each word, underline the prefix, identify the base word, and write the meaning. Then write a paragraph about what you read.
slides.mascot_explanation: Once you've finished your reading adventure and collected all your clues, we'll go back to those sticky notes. In your special journal, you'll write down each word you marked, then show me the prefix part and the base word part, and then figure out what the whole word means. After that, you'll write a little bit about what you read in your chapter.

slides.prompt: Read for 15-20 minutes, flagging prefix words. Then record at least 5 prefix words in your vocabulary journal with full entries. Finally, write a reading response paragraph: summarize what happened in the chapter and share your thoughts or predictions.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to put all your detective skills to work! Read your book for about 15 to 20 minutes and use those sticky notes to mark any words with our prefixes. Then, pick at least five of those words, write them in your journal, break them down into prefix and base word, and write their meanings. Finally, write a paragraph telling me what happened in the part you read and what you thought about it.

slides.text: How many prefix words did you find? Were there any words with prefixes we have not studied yet? The more aware you are of word parts, the stronger your reading becomes. Keep your word detective eyes open!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child independently identify prefixed words while reading and correctly break them into prefix + base word?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You were such an amazing word detective today. How many cool prefix words did you manage to find in your book? It's super smart to notice these word parts because it helps you understand reading even better, like unlocking secret codes in every book you read!

parent_notes: This lesson transfers word study skills to authentic reading — the ultimate goal. If the child finds fewer than 5 prefix words, the book may not have many, or they may need more practice recognizing prefixes in context. Check their identifications to make sure they are correct (not every word starting with 'un' has a prefix — 'uncle' does not have the un- prefix!).

title: Fraction Review — Like Fractions Addition and Fractions of Sets
description: Students consolidate this week's fraction work by completing a variety of problems: adding like fractions, finding fractions of sets, and solving word problems that combine both skills.
instructions:
1. Warm up with 5 quick fraction addition problems.
2. Warm up with 5 quick fraction-of-a-set problems.
3. Solve 3 combined word problems.
4. The child creates a 'Fraction Rule Book' page in their journal.
5. Play a fraction game for fluency.
6. Preview next week: subtracting fractions.

slides.heading: Fraction Review
slides.mascot_explanation: Hey there, super mathematician! This slide is like the title page for our amazing fraction adventure today. We're going to look back at all the cool stuff we learned about adding fractions that have the same bottom number and figuring out what part of a group of things we need.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a mixed problem set. Keep fraction insets and counters accessible. Have dice ready for the game.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, let's get our tools ready for our fraction work! We've got some special shapes called fraction insets that help us see fractions, little counters to represent groups of things, our math journal and pencil for writing and drawing, and two dice for a fun game later. Make sure you have all these handy, and maybe ask a grown-up to help you find them.

slides.text: Quick fire addition: 1/4 + 2/4 = ? 2/6 + 3/6 = ? 1/8 + 5/8 = ? 3/10 + 4/10 = ? 2/5 + 2/5 = ? Work these out mentally, then check with the insets if needed.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for some super speedy math! We're going to do some quick addition problems with fractions. See those fractions? They all have the same bottom number, which makes adding them super easy – just add the top numbers! If you get stuck, you can use those fraction insets to help you see the answer.

slides.text: Quick fraction-of-set: 1/2 of 18 = ? 1/3 of 21 = ? 2/4 of 16 = ? 3/5 of 20 = ? Use counters if you need them.
slides.mascot_explanation: This next part is about finding a piece of a whole group. Imagine you have a bunch of toys, and you need to find just half of them, or maybe a third. We're going to practice finding those parts of numbers using our counters to help us count them out.

slides.text: Combined word problem: 'A farmer has 24 apples. He gives 1/4 to his neighbor and 2/4 to the school. How many apples did he give away in total? How many does he have left?' Use counters AND addition!
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for a little story problem! This one uses both adding fractions and finding parts of groups. Think about the farmer and his apples – you'll need to figure out how many apples he gave away first, and then how many he has left. You can use your counters and your adding skills to solve it!

slides.prompt: Solve the practice problem set in your math journal (10 problems). Then create a 'Fraction Rules' page: write the rules for adding like fractions AND finding fractions of a set, with examples and pictures. Game time: roll 2 dice — one is the numerator, the other is the denominator. Add the fractions you roll!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to show off what you know! You'll solve some practice problems in your journal, and then you'll create your very own "Fraction Rules" page. It's like making your own cheat sheet with the rules for adding fractions and finding parts of groups, with your own examples. After that, we'll play a fun dice game to practice even more!

slides.text: You have mastered two important fraction skills this week! The Fraction Rules page you made is your study guide. Next week, we will learn to subtract fractions — and if you can add, you can subtract!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child add like fractions and find fractions of a set with at least 80% accuracy, and explain the rules in their own words?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You've become a fraction whiz this week, mastering adding fractions and finding parts of groups. That "Fraction Rules" page you made is going to be super helpful for remembering everything. Next week, we'll learn an even cooler trick: subtracting fractions, and guess what? You already know how to do most of it!

parent_notes: This consolidation day is important — do not skip it to move ahead. Fluency with these skills is the foundation for fraction subtraction, mixed numbers, and eventually unlike fractions. The dice game adds fun and randomness. If the child's dice roll creates an improper fraction (like 5/3), preview the concept: 'That is more than one whole! We will learn about those soon.'

title: The Nile River — Detailed Study
description: Students study the Nile River in detail: its source (Lake Victoria), its length (longest river in the world), the cataracts, the delta, and its importance to ancient and modern Egypt.
instructions:
1. Trace the Nile River on a map from source to mouth.
2. Learn key facts: 4,130 miles long, flows north, 6 cataracts.
3. Compare the Nile to other major rivers.
4. Discuss the annual flood: inundation, planting, harvest seasons.
5. The child draws a detailed Nile map with labels.
6. Write a 'biography of the Nile' as if the river were a person.
materials_needed: Map of Africa showing the Nile

slides.heading: The Nile River
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our adventure book about a super special river! It's called the Nile, and guess what? It's the longest river on the whole planet! We're going to learn all about why it's so important.

items: Map of Africa showing the full length of the Nile
Blue string or yarn for tracing
slides.setup_instructions: Display a map of Africa with the Nile clearly visible. Lay out blue string for the child to trace the river's path. Prepare drawing materials.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this activity, we need a few things to become Nile River explorers! We have a map to see where the river is, some blue string to show us its path, paper and coloring tools to draw our own map, and an atlas, which is like a book of maps, to help us find everything. You'll need to gather these with a grown-up's help.

slides.text: The Nile is the longest river in the world at about 4,130 miles — that is like driving from New York to Los Angeles and back! It starts at Lake Victoria in central Africa and flows NORTH (most rivers flow south!) through Uganda, Sudan, and Egypt to the Mediterranean Sea.
slides.mascot_explanation: This part tells us how amazing the Nile is! It's so long, it's like driving across the whole United States! It starts way down south in a big lake called Lake Victoria and flows all the way UP to the sea, which is kind of unusual because most rivers flow down.

slides.text: The Nile has 6 cataracts — rocky, shallow areas where the water rushes and tumbles. These made boat travel difficult. The delta at the mouth looks like a giant fan where the river splits into many channels before reaching the sea.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, imagine a river that sometimes gets a little wild and rocky – those are called cataracts! The Nile has six of them where the water rushes super fast. Also, at the very end, the river spreads out like a big fan, and that's called a delta.

slides.text: Ancient Egyptians divided the year into 3 seasons based on the Nile: Akhet (flooding, June-September), Peret (planting and growing, October-February), and Shemu (harvest, March-May). The flood brought rich black soil — they called their land 'Kemet' meaning 'black land.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Long ago, people who lived by the Nile knew exactly when to plant their crops because of the river's big flood every year! This flood wasn't scary like a flood today; it brought good soil that made their land super fertile, and they even called their land the "black land" because of it.

slides.prompt: Draw a detailed map of the Nile River from Lake Victoria to the Mediterranean Sea. Label: Lake Victoria, White Nile, Blue Nile, the 6 cataracts, Cairo, the Delta, and the Mediterranean. Color the flood zone green. Then write a 'Biography of the Nile' — tell the river's story as if it were a person.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to be an artist and a storyteller! You'll draw your very own map of the Nile, showing where it starts and ends, and marking important places like the cataracts and the fan-shaped delta. Then, you'll write a story about the Nile like it's a person telling its life story!

slides.text: The Nile still flows today, but the Aswan Dam (built in the 1960s) stopped the annual floods. This changed everything about farming in Egypt. Geography shapes history — and human decisions shape geography!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child trace the Nile's path on a map, identify the source and mouth, and explain why the annual flood was important?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you've learned so much about the Nile! Even though the big floods don't happen anymore because of a dam, understanding how rivers like the Nile shaped where people lived and how they farmed is like understanding how history itself happened. You really explored this amazing river!

parent_notes: The Nile is an excellent case study for how geography shapes civilization. The river biography writing activity builds personification skills while reinforcing geography facts. The modern detail about the Aswan Dam shows how human decisions change landscapes — a great discussion starter about environmental impacts. If possible, look at satellite images of the Nile on Google Earth.

title: Egyptian Mummification — Science Meets Culture
description: Students learn about the Egyptian mummification process and the beliefs behind it (preserving the body for the afterlife). They conduct a simplified mummification experiment with an apple.
instructions:
1. Explain Egyptian beliefs about the afterlife: the ka (spirit) needed the body preserved.
2. Describe the mummification process (age-appropriately): washing, removing organs, natron salt, wrapping.
3. Explain canopic jars: special containers for organs.
4. Begin the apple mummification experiment: cut an apple in quarters, treat each differently.
5. Predict which method will best preserve the apple.
6. Discuss the science: salt and drying prevent decomposition.

slides.heading: Mummification
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our exciting book about mummies! It tells us we're going to learn about something called "Mummification," and it's all about how the ancient Egyptians tried to keep bodies safe for a really, really long time, even after they were gone, so they could live forever in the afterlife. Isn't that a wild idea?

items: Mix of salt and baking soda (1/2 cup each, mixed)
slides.setup_instructions: Cut the apple into 4 equal pieces. Label 4 cups: 'Control (nothing),' 'Salt only,' 'Baking soda only,' and 'Salt + Baking soda (Natron).' Have observation sheets ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, here's what we need to make our own mini-mummies! We've got an apple that's already cut into four pieces – those are our "bodies." Then we have salt, baking soda, and a special mix of both that's like the ancient Egyptian's secret ingredient, called natron. We also need four cups to put our apple pieces in, and we'll label them so we remember what we're doing to each one, plus a journal to write down our smart ideas!

slides.text: Ancient Egyptians believed in an afterlife — life after death. They thought the spirit (ka) needed its body to live forever. So they developed mummification — a way to preserve bodies that lasted thousands of years!
slides.mascot_explanation: This part tells us about why the Egyptians did all this! They believed that when someone died, a part of their spirit, called the "ka," was still around and needed a body to live in forever. So, they figured out a super clever way to keep the body from disappearing, kind of like how you might try to keep your favorite toy looking brand new forever!

slides.text: The process took 70 days! They removed internal organs and stored them in canopic jars. They covered the body in natron — a natural salt mixture — to dry it out. Then they wrapped it in linen bandages and placed it in a decorated coffin.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're learning about the actual steps the Egyptians took, and it took them a long, long time – 70 days! They carefully took out the squishy insides, put them in special jars called canopic jars, then covered the whole body in that special salt mixture to dry it out super well, and finally wrapped it up like a mummy in bandages. It sounds like a lot of work, but they really wanted to make sure those bodies lasted!

slides.text: Let us test the science! Place one apple piece in each cup. Cup 1: nothing (control). Cup 2: buried in salt. Cup 3: buried in baking soda. Cup 4: buried in salt + baking soda mix (like natron). Predict: which will be best preserved after one week?
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to be scientists! We're going to put one apple piece in each of our four cups. One cup will have nothing in it, which is like our control – we need something to compare to. The other cups will get buried in salt, baking soda, or the salt and baking soda mix. Your job is to guess which apple piece you think will stay the freshest and least yucky after a whole week!

slides.prompt: Set up the mummification experiment. Draw each cup in your science journal and write your prediction: which apple piece will be best preserved and why? Draw a diagram of the mummification process with labels. We will check the apples in one week!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to do the experiment! Take your apple pieces and carefully place one in each of the four cups, making sure they're covered by whatever is in the cup. Then, open your science journal and draw what each cup looks like, and write down which apple you think will be the best preserved and *why* you think that. You also get to draw a picture of the whole mummy-making process we learned about!

slides.text: We will check our apple mummies next week! The Egyptians discovered through trial and error that salt preserves things — the same science we use today to preserve foods like jerky and pickles.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain why Egyptians mummified bodies, describe the basic process, and make a scientific prediction about the experiment?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we did it! We set up our apple mummification experiment, and now we just have to wait a week to see what happens. Remember how the Egyptians used that special salt mixture? We're doing something similar to see how salt and other things help stop food, or in our case, an apple, from going bad. It's the same science they used to keep their bodies ready for the afterlife!

parent_notes: The apple mummification experiment is a classic Montessori/homeschool activity that beautifully connects history and science. Real natron was a mix of sodium carbonate and sodium bicarbonate (baking soda), so the salt + baking soda mix is a reasonable approximation. Check the apples daily and record observations. The 'natron' cup should preserve best. This experiment takes 1-2 weeks for full results.

title: Read Aloud — Mummies and Mysteries of Egypt
description: Continue the Egypt read-aloud with content about mummies, tombs, and the treasures found inside. Build comprehension through discussion, prediction, and connection to the mummification experiment.
instructions:
1. Review the previous chapter.
2. Read the chapter about mummies and tombs.
3. Connect to today's apple mummification experiment.
4. Discuss: What treasures were buried with pharaohs and why?
5. The child narrates the chapter and writes a journal entry.
6. Make predictions about the next chapter.

slides.heading: Mummies and Mysteries
slides.subheading: Read Aloud — Treasures of the Tombs
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide has the title of our next reading adventure! It's called "Mummies and Mysteries," and we'll be learning all about the amazing things hidden inside ancient Egyptian tombs. It's going to be super exciting, like opening a secret treasure chest!

slides.setup_instructions: Bookmark the mummies chapter. Have both journals ready. If available, show photographs of Tutankhamun's tomb treasures.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide shows us all the special things we'll need for our reading time. We have our Egypt book, which has the chapter about mummies and tombs, and then two special journals: a reading journal for writing down our thoughts and a vocabulary journal for new words. We also need a pencil and some colored pencils to make our journal entries extra special, and make sure you have your bookmark ready for the right page!

slides.text: Review: What did we learn about the pyramids? Today's chapter is about what was INSIDE the pyramids — mummies and treasures! This connects perfectly to our mummification experiment.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, before we dive into the new chapter, let's think about what we already know! Remember those giant pyramids we talked about before? This chapter is going to tell us what was actually hidden *inside* those pyramids and tombs – theummies and all the cool stuff buried with them. It's going to connect really well to the apple experiment we're doing, where we're learning how things can be preserved!

slides.text: Read the chapter aloud. Pause to discuss: 'The Egyptians filled tombs with everything a pharaoh might need in the afterlife: food, clothes, furniture, games, and even model servants called shabti!' What would YOU want in your tomb?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, we get to read the exciting chapter! As we read, listen for all the amazing things the ancient Egyptians put in the tombs for their pharaohs, like food, furniture, and even little statues of helpers. Think about it: if you could have anything you wanted in a special place after you were done living, what would you choose to have with you?

slides.text: After reading: 'In 1922, Howard Carter discovered Tutankhamun's tomb. It was the most incredible archaeological find ever — rooms full of golden treasures that had been sealed for over 3,000 years!' Imagine opening that door!
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, this part is about a super famous discovery! A man named Howard Carter found King Tutankhamun's tomb, and it was packed with incredible golden treasures that nobody had seen for over 3,000 years! Imagine being the first person to open that door and see all those sparkly, ancient things – it must have felt like stepping back in time!

slides.prompt: Narrate the chapter in your own words (tell it back to your parent). In your reading journal, write about: What was the most amazing thing you learned today? How does the mummification process in the book connect to our apple experiment? Add new vocabulary to your journal.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where you get to be the storyteller! After we finish reading, I want you to tell your grown-up all about the chapter in your own words, like you're telling them a cool story. Then, in your reading journal, write down the most surprising thing you learned and how our apple experiment reminds you of the mummies in the book, and don't forget to write down any new words you learned in your vocabulary journal!

slides.text: The treasures of Egypt are still being discovered today! Archaeologists continue to find new tombs and artifacts. What a thrilling chapter of history. Next week, we read about hieroglyphics and the Rosetta Stone!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child narrate the main events of the chapter and explain the connection between mummification beliefs and tomb contents?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! You just learned all about the amazing treasures buried in Egyptian tombs and how the Egyptians believed they'd be used in the afterlife. It's so cool that people are still finding new things from ancient Egypt today! Next time, we'll learn about secret codes called hieroglyphics and a special stone that helped us understand them!

parent_notes: The mummies topic is endlessly fascinating for this age group. If any content seems too intense (organ removal), it can be handled matter-of-factly: 'The Egyptians were very practical about this — they knew the body needed to be dried to last.' The Howard Carter discovery story is a perfect narrative hook. If the child wants more, the Tutankhamun story has been told in many excellent children's books.
